title: Immersion Experience I
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: The course is designed to provide students with opportunities to study and use English in a first language context while engaging themselves with the English culture, thus resulting in gains in language, professional and personal development. The course will be conducted in the format of a study programme to be conducted overseas. The course will include components such as language enhancement, English language teaching techniques, cultural orientation and school experience or the equivalent.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. enhance competence in using English as a means of communication; 2. present ideas effectively in English in academic contexts;  3. have first-hand experience of and gain knowledge about cultures and life styles in countries where English is the mother tongue; 4. expand their repertoire of techniques in teaching English as a foreign language; 5. expand exposure to educational practices in places other than Hong Kong; and 6. provide the opportunity for participants to develop a more global outlook.
syllabus: 1. English language enhancement 2. English language teaching methodology and education 3. Academic English skills 4. School experience 5. Social programme / cultural activities 6. Self-directed learning
recommended_readings: 1. Freed, B.F. (1995). Second language acquisition in a study context abroad. Philadelphia, Pa.: J. Benjamins. 2. Hyland, K. (2006). English for academic purposes: an advanced resource book. London: Routledge 3. MacIntyre, P., Baker, S., Clément, R., & Conrod, S. (2001). Willingness to communicate, social support, and language-learning orientations of immersion students. Studies in Second Language Acquisition, 23(3), 369-388. 4. Pollard, Andrew; Collins, Janet; Simco, Neil; Swaffield, Sue; Warin, Jo and Warwick, Paul (2002). Reflective Teaching: Effective and Evidence-Informed Professional Practice. UK: Continuum. 5. Zeichner, K., Liston, D. (2014). Reflective Teaching. New York: Routledge.

title: English Language Teaching Theory and Methodology
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: This course provides a theoretical foundation to the understanding of English language teaching methodology. Selective methods used in teaching English to non-native speakers in Hong Kong and abroad will be examined. Students will become familiar with the principles governing the curriculum design and implementation of the different English teaching methods. Methods appropriate to child, adolescent, and young adult learners are discussed and demonstrated. Input from the course forms the knowledge base for subsequent courses on English language teaching techniques. Observation of videotapes of lessons and opportunities for peer teaching will be included.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will have: 1. a better understanding of (i) issues involved in analysing teaching practices (ii) theories underlying teaching practices (iii) how historical and alternative methods and approaches impact on the communicative teaching of English 2. developed and applied a framework for the analysis and evaluation of teaching practices in Hong Kong classrooms
syllabus: 1. Theories of second language acquisition 2. Factors affecting second language learning 3. Approaches and methods in language teaching 4. Teaching English language to learners of different age groups 5. Learning culture 6. Learning style and strategies

title: English Language Teaching Techniques I
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: This is the first course of a series of three related courses on practices and techniques of teaching English in Hong Kong schools. These three courses seek to help students develop their theories and practices of language pedagogy and awareness of options available in the language classroom, make informed decisions in the planning and teaching processes and reflect on their teaching styles. Throughout the three courses, special attention will be paid to English language teaching pedagogy for current local curricular developments. These courses will include opportunities for observation of videotaped lessons and peer teaching. The first course focuses on developing the general competency, knowledge, strategies and skills a teacher needs in order to organise effective learning in the language classroom under the aegis of a communicative approach to language teaching and learning. A wide range of techniques and teaching strategies suitable for learners of different ages, proficiency levels and learning needs will be included. Topics include lesson planning, motivating, engaging and interacting with learners, classroom organization and management, dealing with errors, classroom language and using and evaluating learning materials. Teaching of grammar and vocabulary will also be covered.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will: 1. demonstrate an understanding of the current principles and practice of teaching English as a foreign / second language; 2. have developed knowledge, skills and techniques to organise effective teaching of English to learners of different ages and proficiency levels in a classroom setting; and 3. have developed knowledge, skills and techniques to teach grammar and vocabulary to learners of different ages and proficiency levels.
syllabus: 1. Teaching techniques and teaching strategies suitable for learners of different ages, proficiency levels and learning needs 2. Lesson planning 3. Strategies for motivating, engaging and interacting with learners 4. Classroom organization and management 5. Teaching of grammar and dealing with errors 6. Teaching of vocabulary 7. Evaluating grammar and vocabulary instructional materials

title: English Language Teaching Techniques II
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: This course focuses on the teaching of listening and speaking skills. It is designed to develop students' knowledge, strategies and skills for teaching listening and speaking to learners of different proficiency levels and learning needs. The theoretical basis for current practice and the 'how' and the 'what' of teaching these two skills will be examined, demonstrated and practised. Teaching of pronunciation and phonics will also be covered.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. show awareness of the nature of English listening and speaking; 2. identify, express and justify appropriate learning objectives for the teaching of listening and speaking, including pronunciation; 3. plan activities and procedures to support their expressed objectives; 4. express a rationale for choices made during lesson planning; and 5. carry out a teaching plan in front of peers 6. reflect upon their lessons and identify areas of strength and areas for improvement.

description: This course focuses on the teaching of reading and writing skills. title: Language Assessment and Evaluation
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: This course presents the basic principles of language assessment and current practices. It aims to develop a sound understanding of theoretical foundations and key issues of second language assessment, equip students with knowledge and practical skills in language test design, and provide opportunities to evaluate and critique language tests.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. grasp the major principles underpinning language testing and assessment;  2. explain the different purposes of language assessment and understand how assessment for learning and assessment as learning can be used to promote learning and improve teaching; 3. acquire relevant techniques to construct language tests that focus on grammar, vocabulary, speaking, listening, reading and writing; 4. evaluate and critique language tests used in local schools by applying the assessment principles learnt from the course; 5. enhance their assessment literacy for effective English language teaching.
syllabus: 1. Key assessment concepts 2. Assessment for and as learning and alternative assessment  3. Test construction 4. Assessment of language skills  5. Feedback for effective student learning 6. Critique of language tests 7. Critical discussion and reflection on language assessment in real classroom contexts

title: Studying Second Language Learners and Classrooms
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: This course provides an introduction to classroom-based research, with a view to sensitizing students to the complexity of language learning in the classroom, and equipping them with the skills of collecting and analysing language teaching and learning data. Major research methods in language teaching, in particular action research, are covered. Students will develop a research proposal during the course and collect data during their teaching practice.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. show awareness of different research designs, and reasons for choosing between them; 2. identify the steps needed to carry out a piece of classroom-based research; 3. express a research focus and develop research questions; 4. justify choice of data collection methods; 5. evaluate data collection and analysis; 6. write up a proposal for classroom-based research; and 7. demonstrate academic literacy (including academic honesty).
syllabus: 1. Types of classroom-based research 2. Selecting and developing a topic for investigation 3. Generating research questions 4. The ‘why’ and ‘how’ of literature review 5. Research design and methodology 6. Data collection methods 7. Data analysis methods 8. Write up of a proposal for an investigative study 9. Academic literacy

title: English Language Teaching Project Report
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: This course builds on the prerequisite course entitled ‘Studying Second Language Learners and Classroom’, which provides an introduction to classroom-based research. Course participants have already prepared a research proposal for the prerequisite course. In the teaching practice, they will undertake the research project that they have proposed and submit a report on the study for course assessment. The aim of the two courses is to provide course participants, who are student teachers of English as a second language, an opportunity to conduct a study in the classroom for a better understanding of the teacher, the learners and classroom teaching and learning.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will have: 1. acquired the experience of conducting a classroom-based study in a real classroom setting on a topic of their choice; 2. acquired the experience of writing up a report for a classroom-based study; 3. acquired the experience of presenting their proposals to an academic audience; 4. become familiar with the steps taken to conduct a classroom-based study;  5. developed skills in data analysis and data presentation; 6. been able to draw conclusions and implications from the findings of their own classroom-based study; 7. gained a better understanding of the area of their study; 8. sharpened academic writing skills;  9. developed a foundation for further research in terms of understanding of the research process; and 10. developed positive attitudes towards professional development via conducting classroom-based research
syllabus: 1. Qualitative data analysis 2. Quantitative data analysis 3. Writing up of the different parts of a complete research paper 4. Presenting a research paper 5. Research ethics

title: Materials Development and Adaptation
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: Given that effective instructional materials are able to enrich learning experience and enhance learners' attention engagement in classrooms, this course aims to equip students with the principles and skills of materials development (materials design, selection, adaptation and evaluation) for ELT through lectures, group discussions and workshops. The following topics will be included: (a) an overview of different language learning models and instructional principles for formulating materials design principles that suit students' future teaching contexts; (b) the relationship between instructional methods, syllabus, and instructional materials; (c) the use of ELT instructional materials such as text books, authentic materials and multimedia materials; (d) materials selection, adaptation and evaluation. Throughout the course, students will be provided with practical experience of evaluating and adapting text books, and designing tasks requiring the use of authentic / multimedia materials in classrooms.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. have a better theoretical understanding of the relationship between language teaching approaches, syllabus design and materials development, and recognize how the different models of language teaching would result in differences for instructional methods, syllabus design and materials development; 2. formulate materials design principles that suit their future teaching context; 3. evaluate materials in use e.g. text books, authentic materials, multimedia materials….etc in their future teaching contexts, and select from, adapt or supplement these materials to make ELT classroom learning experience more interesting; and 4. design authentic and communicative language task for the use of authentic materials in ELT classrooms.
syllabus: 1. Issues and trends in materials development Understanding language curriculum 2. instructional design; needs assessment 3. Material evaluation 4. Technology in material development 5. Materials for teaching Grammar 6. Materials for teaching Vocabulary 7. Materials for developing Reading skills 8. Materials for developing Writing skills 9. title: Information and Multimedia Technology and English Language Teaching
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: This course covers the application of computers and associated technology for English language teaching, providing an overview of the uses of Computer Assisted Language Learning in schools. Topics include English language teaching software evaluation, interactive instructional technologies, multimedia, the Internet in English language teaching, and English language teaching curriculum applications. The major emphasis is on determining the needs / applications of computers in English language teaching in Hong Kong schools. Participants in the course are provided with hands-on experience in using and evaluating English language teaching software.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. have a perspective of CALL with regard to the 'history' of IT and the learning theories that underlie different approaches to the use of IT in English language teaching; 2. develop a framework for understanding CALL materials and for putting them into perspective; 3. be able to critically analyse CALL programs and materials; and 4. evaluate the value of IT as a teaching tool – in terms of what can and cannot be reasonably achieved in developing students' English language skills.
syllabus: 1. Professional development for CALL teachers; PD groups and activities; CALL journals and references; tools for teachers 2. Language investigation (corpus linguistics, online dictionaries, pronunciation dictionaries; etc.) 3. Teacher language awareness and grammar teaching: capitalizing on technology 4. Teaching Vocabulary , Listening, Speaking, Reading Comprehension; and Writing with technology 5. Projects and their visual presentation Integrating e-learning with Flipped Learning 6. Strategies to develop technology-enhanced learning) 7. Engaging Students inside and outside the classroom for technology-enhanced learning

title: Current Issues in English Language Teaching
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: This course examines recent policy initiatives, curriculum developments, research or key projects in English and / or English language teaching in Hong Kong or overseas. The background and implications of these issues on the teaching and learning of English will be analysed. Ways to address these issues at the school and classroom levels will also be explored.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will: 1. have a basic understanding of the theoretical / contextual backgrounds of the issue(s) being examined; 2. be able to analyse critically the implications of the issue(s) on the teaching and learning of English in general; and 3. be able to apply the input from the course to address the needs in their professional contexts.
syllabus: 1. Overview of the issues 2. Critical analysis of the issue 3. Pedagogical implications
recommended_readings: Reference materials will focus on the issue(s) being examined in the course.

title: English Language Teaching Curriculum Theory and Design
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: The course is designed to develop an appreciation of the central and emergent ideas in curriculum theory as it relates to English language teaching. Students examine the characteristics and assumptions of various types of language syllabuses. The course also critically reviews the processes of syllabus construction (e.g., needs analysis, content selection, sub-division, grading and sequencing) as well as curriculum implementation, management, and evaluation. Case studies of curricular problems in Hong Kong are analysed.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. increase awareness of the theories and issues relating to the English language curriculum; 2. develop informed and critical approaches to recent and current developments in this area; 3. plan and implement effective improvements to overall ELT curriculum design, use of instructional materials, assessment and teaching; 4. offer informed knowledge and understanding of teaching activities with reference to the ELT curriculum; and 5. evaluate the effectiveness of ELT curriculum.
syllabus: 1. Curriculum theory and design 2. Hong Kong English Language curriculum 3. Needs analysis in curriculum development 4. Role and design of instructional materials 5. Effective teaching 6. Role and design of English Language assessment 7. Curriculum evaluation
recommended_readings: 1. Brown, J.D.B. (2001). The Elements of Language Curriculum: A Systematic Approach to Program Development. Heinle & Heinle Publishers. 2. Richards, J.C. (2001). Curriculum Development in Language Teaching. Cambridge: CUP. 3. Nation, P. and Mcalister, J. (2009). Language Curriculum Design. Routledge

title: Teaching English Through Language Arts
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: This course examines the place of language arts in the English language curriculum and focuses on methods and techniques through which language arts can be used to enhance students' English language skills within a communicative approach to language teaching and learning. A wide range of genres including drama, novels, short stories, poems, films, songs, etc. will be covered.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will: 1. be able to demonstrate an understanding of the place of language arts in language education, focusing on the Experience Strand of the English Language curriculum; 2. become familiar with language-based approaches to literature to enhance awareness of the properties of language use in literary materials in the light of communicative language resources; 3. be able to demonstrate skills in language arts materials selection, textual analysis and task design for integration into language teaching curricular; and 4. have fostered interest in reading different language arts genres for pleasure and for language enrichment.
syllabus: 1. Towards characterizing language arts 2. The place of and approaches to language arts in the English language curriculum 3. Teaching English through short stories 4. Teaching English through poems 5. Teaching English through plays 6. Teaching English through songs 7. Teaching English through pop culture 8. Teaching English through films
recommended_readings: 1. Parkinson, B., & Thomas, H. R. (2000). Teaching literature in a second language (pp. 40-52). Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press. 2. Hall, G. (2005). title: Enrichment Activities for English Language Teaching
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: This course introduces a range of language activities that supplement the coursebook and the formal curriculum. Such activities help to enliven the learning experience, provide exposure to authentic language, and create opportunities for communicative language use. Example sources are the mass media, songs and rhymes, communication games, and leisure reading materials. Extra-curricular activities that provide enjoyable learning experiences include drama, debating, publishing, choral speaking, etc.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. understand the principles that underlie English enrichment activities; 2. plan and organize language enrichment activities to enhance students' language learning experience; 3. conduct and evaluate language enrichment activities effectively; and 4. integrate language enrichment activities into the formal and informal curricula.
syllabus: 1. To introduce course participants to a range of language enrichment activities (LEA). 2. To equip course participants with the professional skills of: (i) selecting, adapting and designing LEA that suit the teaching context they are in to complement the textbooks and the formal curriculum;  (ii) adopting effective teaching strategies for using LEA to teach English in formal classroom learning context; and (iii) integrating formal and informal curricular through the use of LEA. 3. To further enhance use of classroom language. 4. To develop generic skills such as creativity, communication skills, interpersonal skills, presentation skills and collaboration skills.
recommended_readings: 1. Lee, I., Lee, M. & Ng, R. (1994). Fun after hours: Extra-curricular activities in secondary schools. Hong Kong: Institute of Language in Education. 2. Man, E., Coniam, D., Lee. I., Bruce, C., Tam, C., Cheung, A. & Chau, A. (2003). Establishing an English-rich environment in EMI schools. Hong Kong: The Chinese University of Hong Kong. 3. Mok, A. (1997). English language enrichment programme resource book. Hong Kong: INSTEP, University of Hong Kong.

title: Special Topics in English Language Teaching
academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
description: From time to time the Faculty will offer courses that will focus on an area of English language teaching that is not already covered in the regular programme of studies. These topics will reflect professional needs / interests and Faculty expertise as well as addressing new developments in English language teaching in Hong Kong.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will: 1. have a basic understanding of the concepts outlined in relation to the topic(s) being examined; and 2. be able to apply the input from the course to enhance the effectiveness of the teaching and learning of English at the school /classroom levels.
syllabus: 1. Overview of the topic 2. Critical analysis of the topic 3. Pedagogical implications
recommended_readings: Reference materials will focus on the topic(s) being examined in the course.
